channel.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
channel.description:
Prove me wrong.
Part 1:
[code] class PacketHandler def method_missing(sym) raise "Unhandled Packet: #{sym}" end
def handle_14 puts "Handling login..." end end
# build a packet from some data somewhere packet = Packet.new(@data) handlers = PacketHandler.new handlers.send "handle_#{packet.opcode}" [/code]

item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

mopman i think this is better in many many many ways

item.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:28, topic:367765”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=463913.msg3396124#msg3396124 date=1289413258]
uh, but both of those examples don’t do the same thing as mine. again, the point was not what the code did, but to demonstrate language features, namely metaprogramming and yielding to a passed block (im sure that has to have a better name :/)

also not sure if you’re aware from your post, but ruby is strongly typed. it will raise an exception if you try to assign a value to a type that it doesn’t make sense. there’s no way to give the vm a type hint without actually assigning to it, tho (whee duck typing)
[/quote][/quote]

I don’t understand this so perl is still better…

Read full topic

item.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:4, topic:367765”]Part 3

[code]

ruby-1.9.2-p0 > class Fixnum
ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> def my_times
ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> for i in 1…self do
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > yield
ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> end
ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> end
ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> end
=> nil
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > 5.my_times { puts ‘la’ }
la
la
la
la
la
=> 1…5
ruby-1.9.2-p0 >
[/code][/quote]

for ($i; $i <@ARGV[0]; $i++) { print @ARGV[1] . "\n"; }

C:\Documents\Niall\Desktop>perl loop.pl 5 la
la
la
la
la
la

[quote=“Mopman, post:5, topic:367765”]Part 4 (not that nifty, just thought frank might hate it)

ruby-1.9.2-p0 > x = "frank" => "frank" ruby-1.9.2-p0 > x.upcase => "FRANK" ruby-1.9.2-p0 > class String ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> def upcase(*args) ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> self.reverse! ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> end ruby-1.9.2-p0 ?> end => nil ruby-1.9.2-p0 > x.upcase => "knarf" [/quote]

$x = "frank"; print uc($x) . "\n"; print reverse($x) . "\n";

C:\Documents\Niall\Desktop>perl str.pl
FRANK
knarf

Read full topic

item.source: Things Ruby does better than your language

item.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

Personally, I prefer

10.times { |x| # Do shit }

to

for(int x = 0; x < 10; x++) {
    // Shit
}

Also the ability to do stuff like:

while gets
    break if /^exit$/
    print if /^\d+$/
end

Another thing I like, is the ability to use a String in a ‘case’ and match it via regular expressions:

data = "exec date"

case data
when /^exec (.+)$/
  puts `#{$1}`
when /^echo (.+)$/
  puts $1
end

Just some features I like about Ruby lol

Read full topic
item.source: Things Ruby does better than your language

item.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

uh, but both of those examples don’t do the same thing as mine. again, the point was not what the code did, but to demonstrate language features, namely metaprogramming and yielding to a passed block (im sure that has to have a better name :/)

also not sure if you’re aware from your post, but ruby is strongly typed. it will raise an exception if you try to assign a value to a type that it doesn’t make sense. there’s no way to give the vm a type hint without actually assigning to it, tho (whee duck typing)

Read full topic
item.source: Things Ruby does better than your language

item.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:18, topic:367765”]do the first example in actionscript, and then see how its much less elegant and 3x as much code

the topic was mainly meant to poke fun at bad scripting languages, its not about doing things other languages can’t its about doing them more elegantly[/quote]
Since I’m not very experienced in AS 3.0 and don’t really understand your first example I would not to that. But I will show you 2 of the other ones.

function reverse(str:String) { var sTmp = ""; for (var i = str.length - 1; i >= 0; i--)sTmp += str.charAt(i); return sTmp; } trace(reverse("frank")); // Output: knarf function spam(string:String, times:Number){ for (var i = 0; i < times; i++) trace(string); } spam("la",5); //Output: // la // la // la // la // la
What i really meant, was both Actionscript and Ruby have simple way to create function, variables and Class. Nothing about Actionscript was able to to your examples better.
But Actionscript have a nice feature missing in Ruby, in AS you can set datatype to a variable, you don’t have to use it, but you are getting nice error message if you (For instance:) somewhere in the code are using an string instead of number.

And I know my code is not very elegant, but do you find the elegance in Ruby everywhere, and is the elegance worth it?

Read full topic
item.source: Things Ruby does better than your language

item.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:16, topic:367765”]the examples were to demonstrate specific language features rather than be meaningful in the their own way

for example the knarf one wasnt to demonstrate reverse but the point that all objects are mutable, you can overload existing methods on anything, even the standard library[/quote]
My point is, that the code you are posting, are nothing that does Ruby superior.
Yes, there is one thing, simple creating of classes, functions and variables compared to C++ and Java, but that does Actionscript (3.0) handle very well too.

Read full topic

item.title: Things Ruby does better than your language
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

the examples were to demonstrate specific language features rather than be meaningful in the their own way

for example the knarf one wasnt to demonstrate reverse but the point that all objects are mutable, you can overload existing methods on anything, even the standard library
